message.content:
Implement the following plan:

# Changelog Page — Content Collections Data Source

## Context

Changelog page UI is mostly built (timeline, entry component, route, footer link). Currently uses a hardcoded array in `lib/changelog.ts`. Need to swap to Content Collections so entries are authored as MDX files — same pattern as the blog. This decouples changelog from GitHub releases (which are auto-tagged per PR, too granular).

## Files

### Create

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `src/content/changelog/*.mdx` | Changelog entries (4 seed files) |
| `src/lib/changelog-posts.ts` | Export `allChangelogs` from content-collections, filter drafts |

### Modify

| File | Change |
|------|--------|
| `content-collections.ts` | Add `changelog` collection with its own schema |
| `src/lib/changelog.ts` | Remove hardcoded entries array, keep types + `CATEGORY_LABELS` |
| `src/routes/changelog.tsx` | Import from `changelog-posts.ts` instead of `changelog.ts` |
| `src/components/changelog-entry.tsx` | Adapt to content-collections shape (minor field mapping) |

## Content Collections Setup

Add a `changelog` collection in `content-collections.ts` alongside `posts`:

```ts
const changelog = defineCollection({
  name: "changelog",
  directory: "./src/content/changelog",
  include: "**/*.mdx",
  schema: z.object({
    title: z.string(),
    published: z.iso.date(),
    draft: z.boolean().default(false),
    category: z.enum(["data", "feature", "improvement", "community"]),
    summary: z.string(),
    content: z.string(),
  }),
  transform: async (document, context) => {
    const mdx = await compileMDX(context, document, {
      remarkPlugins: [remarkGfm],
    });
    return {
      ...document,
      slug: document._meta.path,
      mdx,
    };
  },
});
```

Register: `collections: [posts, changelog]`

## MDX File Format

```mdx
---
title: PLL 2025 Season Data
published: 2026-01-15
category: data
summary: Complete game-by-game statistics for the 2025 PLL season.
---

Body content here as markdown. Supports **bold**, lists, etc.

- 156 games across 8 teams
- Player stats: goals, assists, points, ground balls
```

Key difference from hardcoded model: `body[]` and `highlights[]` merge into a single MDX body. Simpler to author, richer formatting.

## Entry Component Adaptation

The `ChangelogEntryCard` currently renders `body[]` as paragraphs and `highlights[]` as bullet list. With MDX, the component renders compiled MDX directly using the existing `prose-blog` styles (or a lighter variant). The `summary` stays in frontmatter for the timeline preview text.

## Data Flow

```
src/content/changelog/*.mdx
  → content-collections build (bun run gen:content-collections)
  → allChangelogs (typed array)
  → changelog-posts.ts (filter drafts, sort by date)
  → route imports sorted array
  → ChangelogEntryCard renders each entry
```

## Implementation Order

1. Add `changelog` collection to `content-collections.ts`
2. Create `src/content/changelog/` with 4 seed MDX files
3. Create `src/lib/changelog-posts.ts`
4. Update `changelog-entry.tsx` to render MDX body
5. Update `routes/changelog.tsx` to use new data source
6. Clean up `lib/changelog.ts` (remove entries array, keep types)
7. Run `bun run gen:content-collections` + typecheck

## Verification

1. `bun run gen:content-collections`
2. `bun run dev` → `localhost:3002/changelog`
3. Verify entries render with formatted MDX body
4. `bun run typecheck` passes


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/jw/.REDACTED.jsonl

If this plan can be broken down into multiple independent tasks, consider using the TeamCreate tool to create a team and parallelize the work.

planContent:
# Changelog Page — Content Collections Data Source

## Context

Changelog page UI is mostly built (timeline, entry component, route, footer link). Currently uses a hardcoded array in `lib/changelog.ts`. Need to swap to Content Collections so entries are authored as MDX files — same pattern as the blog. This decouples changelog from GitHub releases (which are auto-tagged per PR, too granular).

## Files

### Create

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `src/content/changelog/*.mdx` | Changelog entries (4 seed files) |
| `src/lib/changelog-posts.ts` | Export `allChangelogs` from content-collections, filter drafts |

### Modify

| File | Change |
|------|--------|
| `content-collections.ts` | Add `changelog` collection with its own schema |
| `src/lib/changelog.ts` | Remove hardcoded entries array, keep types + `CATEGORY_LABELS` |
| `src/routes/changelog.tsx` | Import from `changelog-posts.ts` instead of `changelog.ts` |
| `src/components/changelog-entry.tsx` | Adapt to content-collections shape (minor field mapping) |

## Content Collections Setup

Add a `changelog` collection in `content-collections.ts` alongside `posts`:

```ts
const changelog = defineCollection({
  name: "changelog",
  directory: "./src/content/changelog",
  include: "**/*.mdx",
  schema: z.object({
    title: z.string(),
    published: z.iso.date(),
    draft: z.boolean().default(false),
    category: z.enum(["data", "feature", "improvement", "community"]),
    summary: z.string(),
    content: z.string(),
  }),
  transform: async (document, context) => {
    const mdx = await compileMDX(context, document, {
      remarkPlugins: [remarkGfm],
    });
    return {
      ...document,
      slug: document._meta.path,
      mdx,
    };
  },
});
```

Register: `collections: [posts, changelog]`

## MDX File Format

```mdx
---
title: PLL 2025 Season Data
published: 2026-01-15
category: data
summary: Complete game-by-game statistics for the 2025 PLL season.
---

Body content here as markdown. Supports **bold**, lists, etc.

- 156 games across 8 teams
- Player stats: goals, assists, points, ground balls
```

Key difference from hardcoded model: `body[]` and `highlights[]` merge into a single MDX body. Simpler to author, richer formatting.

## Entry Component Adaptation

The `ChangelogEntryCard` currently renders `body[]` as paragraphs and `highlights[]` as bullet list. With MDX, the component renders compiled MDX directly using the existing `prose-blog` styles (or a lighter variant). The `summary` stays in frontmatter for the timeline preview text.

## Data Flow

```
src/content/changelog/*.mdx
  → content-collections build (bun run gen:content-collections)
  → allChangelogs (typed array)
  → changelog-posts.ts (filter drafts, sort by date)
  → route imports sorted array
  → ChangelogEntryCard renders each entry
```

## Implementation Order

1. Add `changelog` collection to `content-collections.ts`
2. Create `src/content/changelog/` with 4 seed MDX files
3. Create `src/lib/changelog-posts.ts`
4. Update `changelog-entry.tsx` to render MDX body
5. Update `routes/changelog.tsx` to use new data source
6. Clean up `lib/changelog.ts` (remove entries array, keep types)
7. Run `bun run gen:content-collections` + typecheck

## Verification

1. `bun run gen:content-collections`
2. `bun run dev` → `localhost:3002/changelog`
3. Verify entries render with formatted MDX body
4. `bun run typecheck` passes

input.content:
---
title: PLL 2025 Season Data
published: 2026-01-15
category: data
summary: Complete game-by-game statistics for the 2025 PLL season are now available, including the league's first full season of two-point tracking.
---

We've ingested and normalized every box score from the 2025 Premier Lacrosse League season. This includes regular season, playoffs, and the championship series — 156 games total across all 8 teams.

This is the first PLL season where two-point shot data was tracked consistently from game one, giving us a much clearer picture of how the two-point line is changing offensive strategy at the pro level.

- 156 games across 8 teams
- Player stats: goals, assists, points, ground balls, caused turnovers
- Goalie stats: saves, goals against, save percentage
- Full two-point shot tracking (attempts, makes, percentage)

content.content: File created successfully at: /Users/jw/Desktop/repos/laxdb/packages/marketing/src/content/changelog/pll-2025-season-data.mdx

---
title: PLL 2025 Season Data
published: 2026-01-15
category: data
summary: Complete game-by-game statistics for the 2025 PLL season are now available, including the league's first full season of two-point tracking.
---

We've ingested and normalized every box score from the 2025 Premier Lacrosse League season. This includes regular season, playoffs, and the championship series — 156 games total across all 8 teams.

This is the first PLL season where two-point shot data was tracked consistently from game one, giving us a much clearer picture of how the two-point line is changing offensive strategy at the pro level.

- 156 games across 8 teams
- Player stats: goals, assists, points, ground balls, caused turnovers
- Goalie stats: saves, goals against, save percentage
- Full two-point shot tracking (attempts, makes, percentage)

input.content:
---
title: Knowledge Graph Explorer
published: 2025-12-02
category: feature
summary: A new interactive force-directed graph lets you explore connections between players, teams, and seasons visually.
---

The knowledge graph is one of the things that makes LaxDB different from a spreadsheet. Every entity in our database — players, teams, seasons, games — is connected by typed relationships. The new graph explorer makes those connections browsable.

Click any node to expand its connections. Filter by relationship type. Search for a player and see every team they've played for, every teammate they've shared a roster with, and how those connections branch outward.

- Interactive force-directed layout with zoom and pan
- Color-coded nodes: players, teams, seasons, leagues
- Click-to-expand exploration pattern
- Shareable URLs for any graph state

content.content: File created successfully at: /Users/jw/Desktop/repos/laxdb/packages/marketing/src/content/changelog/knowledge-graph-explorer.mdx

Click any node to expand its connections. Filter by relationship type. Search for a player and see every team they've played for, every teammate they've shared a roster with, and how those connections branch outward.

input.content:
---
title: NLL Historical Stats 1987–2024
published: 2025-11-10
category: data
summary: 37 seasons of National Lacrosse League data, from the Eagle Pro era through the modern NLL. The deepest box lacrosse dataset available anywhere.
---

This was our most ambitious data project to date. The NLL (originally the Eagle Pro Inline Hockey League, then the Major Indoor Lacrosse League) has existed in various forms since 1987, and its historical data has been scattered across defunct league websites, PDFs, and fan archives.

We've assembled, verified, and normalized stats from every season. Where official records had gaps, we cross-referenced multiple sources. The result is a continuous statistical record for every franchise, including through relocations and name changes.

- 37 seasons of player and team statistics
- Franchise history tracking through relocations (e.g. Philadelphia Wings to New York Riptide)
- Career stats spanning the full NLL/MILL/EPBLL history
- Season-by-season league leaders for major categories

This was our most ambitious data project to date. The NLL (originally the Eagle Pro Inline Hockey League, then the Major Indoor Lacrosse League) has existed in various forms since 1987, and its historical data has been scattered across defunct league websites, PDFs, and fan archives.

We've assembled, verified, and normalized stats from every season. Where official records had gaps, we cross-referenced multiple sources. The result is a continuous statistical record for every franchise, including through relocations and name changes.

input.content:
---
title: LaxDB Goes Open Source
published: 2025-10-20
category: community
summary: The full LaxDB stack — data pipeline, API, and marketing site — is now open source on GitHub.
---

From day one, we've believed that lacrosse data should be a public good. Today we're making that belief concrete by open-sourcing the entire platform. The data pipeline that ingests and normalizes stats, the API that serves them, and this marketing site are all available under the MIT license.

We're hoping this makes it easier for the lacrosse community to build on top of this data. Whether you're a stats-focused content creator, a coach building scouting tools, or a developer who happens to love lacrosse — the data and the infrastructure to serve it are yours to use.

- Full stack: pipeline, API, web app, marketing site
- MIT license — use it however you want
- Contributions welcome: data corrections, new league support, features
- Built with Effect-TS, TanStack, Drizzle, Cloudflare Workers

content.text:
**Step 7:** Generate content collections and typecheck. The `posts` collection currently uses `./src/content` as its directory — I need to make sure the changelog MDX files in `./src/content/changelog/` don't get picked up by the `posts` collection too. Let me check.

The `posts` collection uses `directory: "./src/content"` with `include: "**/*.mdx"` — that would recursively pick up `changelog/*.mdx` files too. I need to exclude the changelog subdirectory from posts.
I need to exclude `changelog/` from the posts collection so blog posts don't pick up changelog entries.

  directory: "./src/content",
  include: "**/*.mdx",
  exclude: "changelog/**",

content.text:
Confirmed — only 3 pre-existing errors, none related to changelog. My changes typecheck cleanly.

Here's a summary of what was done:

**Created:**
- `content-collections.ts` — added `changelog` collection with schema (title, published, category, summary, draft) + MDX compilation; added `exclude: "changelog/**"` to `posts` to prevent overlap
- `src/content/changelog/` — 4 seed MDX files matching the original hardcoded entries
- `src/lib/changelog-posts.ts` — exports `publishedChangelogs` (draft-filtered, date-sorted), mirrors `posts.ts` pattern

**Modified:**
- `src/components/changelog-entry.tsx` — accepts `Changelog` type from content-collections; renders MDX body via `<MDXContent>` instead of manual `body[]`/`highlights[]` rendering
- `src/routes/changelog.tsx` — imports from `changelog-posts.ts`; sorting moved to the data source
- `src/lib/changelog.ts` — removed hardcoded entries array, kept `ChangelogCategory` type and `CATEGORY_LABELS`
